scenario: At WASP summer school. A presentation of previous year's submissions is shown.

dialogue.line: This is appalling! They actually spent research funding on this?
Well, they were exploring generative models, Sheldon. Isn't that interesting?
Interesting? This can't be the work of PhDs. It's bad, even for a 5-year-old.
Exploring is a generous term. This is more like aimless wandering.
Maybe they had issues with their drivers. Speaking of which, Nvidia is having a presentation soon.

scenario: Nvidia presents their new cloud solution and GPUs

dialogue.line: Ah, Nvidia's cloud solutions. That's how they solve the 'It works on my machine' problem. It works on my machine if everybody uses their machine.
And let's not forget the cost! It's like they're turning electricity into disappointment.
I think it's innovative. It might even help us in the assignment.
Good luck getting early access, unless you want to mortgage your house.
With those prices, even if you could afford it, all you'd generate is a cloud of buyer's remorse.
The more you buy the more you save! Guys should stop clouding the issue.

scenario: The group is sitting and working on the group project

dialogue.line: Isn't it nice that we can use Nvidia's cloud for our project?
Nice? I didn't come to a research event to be 'nice.' I came to show my intellectual superiority.
Well, good luck demonstrating that with these snail-paced servers.
Are the servers also made by a 5-year-old?
No, not a 5-year-old, it's the handiwork of Mr. Windows laptop over there.

scenario: Frustration over slow servers and ungrounded models

dialogue.line: I can't work under these conditions! Slow servers, stochastic models; it's like they're trying to test my patience.
Well, sometimes experimentation is more about the journey than the destination, Sheldon.
A journey? I don't recall signing up for a Lewis and Clark expedition through computational irrelevance.
Right, because who needs actual, grounded theory when you can just roll the dice?
Well, Leonard has a point. Sometimes you have to explore before you find what you're looking for.
Speaking of rolling the dice, aren't we supposed to watch a 3D film tonight? Maybe something will finally jump out at us.
A 3D film sounds like a nice break from all this.
I can't wait to see the 3D film 'Making Magic'. It's going to be fun!
I must admit, a 3D visualization of scientific phenomena might offer some solace for today's shortcomings.

scenario: During the final presentation, no winners are announced

dialogue.line: Ladies and gentlemen, let's not dance around the issue. Since the organizers have, in their infinite wisdom, decided not to declare a winner, I'd like to offer a suggestion: My project was the best!
Sheldon, remember, the essence of this summer school was about collaboration and exploration, not just winning.
Ah yes, collaboration. That's academic speak for 'Let others ride on your coattails.'
Collaboration, stochastic models, slow servers... It's been a roller coaster, hasn't it?
It's true, we've all had our share of challenges. But that's what makes science interesting.
Well, challenges or not, you guys made it! Congrats on surviving the summer school. Drinks are on me!
I never say no to celebratory drinks.
Very well. I suppose a communal celebration is warrantedâ€”even if it blurs the lines of individual merit.
